  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  drums, scorching acidic 303, African beats and, as they do            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  here, classical string arrangements.                                  Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Rising through repeated aural assaults, break beat break              Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  downs and a quirky Leo Nocentelli funky guitar line, &#039;Come            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  With Us&#039; charges like a genetically modified funk rock rhino          Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  into the tribal trance of last year&#039;s single, &#039;It Began In            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Africa&#039;.                                                              Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  &#039;Africa&#039; is competent but next to the engaging,                       Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  work-in-progress quirky funk of &#039;Galaxy Bounce&#039;, it seems             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  straight. All of which makes the appeal of the soon to be             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  released &#039;Star Guitar&#039; single more odd.                               Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Combining a slightly tweaked house drum pattern with gushing          Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  swells of trance synth lines and an ambient, occasionally             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Balearic, feel, the formulae here is far from original. But           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  it&#039;s won applause wherever it&#039;s been played. Once again the           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  secret of its success is in the production, where the                 Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  endemic fragility of the song is given depth by the                   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  contrastingly harsh drum sounds.                                      Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  But perhaps the greatest achievement of &#039;Come With Us&#039; is             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  its stamina, with one of the most interesting contributions,          Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  the multi textural &#039;Hoops&#039;, only coming half way through the          Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  playing order. It may not be the obvious single, but it&#039;s             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  probably the album&#039;s finest moment.                                   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  &#039;My Elastic Eye&#039; again collides the delicate and ephemeral            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  with harsh electronica, and with more devastating effect              Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  than the comparatively safe &#039;Star Guitar&#039;.                            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  The theme of organic fragility jutted against electronic              Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  energy is repeated in Beth Ortan&#039;s plaintive vocals on &#039;The           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  State We&#039;re In&#039;, in which she struggles against keyboards             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  and effects that in anybody else&#039;s studio would have been             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  too high in the mix. Here it seems to work.                           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Juxtaposed to this comes &#039;Denmark&#039;, a bass driven disco               Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  stomp that clatters along on early Nineties Knuckle&#039;s wood            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  blocks before the full drum kit takes over the percussion             Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  and a bass drill pounds into the &#039;Pig Bag&#039; bass line.                 Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Further pushing the boundaries, &#039;Pioneer Skies&#039;, an                   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  awesomely large production for its length, sounds like pure           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Pete Townshend circa his &#039;Who&#039;s Next&#039; prog era.                       Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Finally the plodding drum rolls of &#039;Pioneer Skies&#039;,                   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â° (should be &#039;The Test&#039;, looks like a minor error on the editor&#039;s side)  Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  featuring Richard Ashcroft, offer the album&#039;s largest olive           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  branch to the unrepentant unconverted.                                Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Unlike their recent offerings, &#039;Come With Us&#039; doesn&#039;t rely            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  on collaborations to cross over into different markets. Nor           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  does it turn out tub-thumping dance music to capture the              Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  club contingent.                                                      Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Rather, like their earlier offerings, it matches big sound            Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  crowd-pleasing gimmicks with the cerebrally challenging and           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  adventurous. It exposes the unmatched raw nerve of Chemical           Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  Brothers&#039; production and spikes it with innovation.                   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°                                                                        Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
  Ãƒâ€ºÃ‚Â°  A subtly brutal and powerfully fragile masterpiece." -- Ben Osborne   Ã‚Â°Ãƒâ€º
